text: We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
author: Seneca
context: On the futility of anticipatory anxiety

text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
author: Seneca

text: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
author: Seneca

text: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
author: Seneca

text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
author: Seneca

text: True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.
author: Seneca

text: If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.
author: Seneca

text: We are always complaining that our days are few, and acting as though there would be no end of them.
author: Seneca

text: Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.
author: Seneca

text: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
author: Seneca

text: It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.
author: Seneca

text: Life is long if you know how to use it.
author: Seneca

text: No person has the power to have everything they want, but it is in their power not to want what they don't have.
author: Seneca

text: We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more from imagination than from reality.
author: Seneca

text: Hang on to your youthful enthusiasms — you'll be able to use them better when you're older.
author: Seneca

text: Every night before going to sleep, we must ask ourselves: what weakness did I overcome today? What virtue did I acquire?
author: Seneca

text: The mind that is anxious about future events is miserable.
author: Seneca

text: Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom you yourself can improve.
author: Seneca

text: While we are postponing, life speeds by.
author: Seneca

text: Nothing is burdensome if taken lightly, and nothing need arouse irritation so long as it doesn't set off our anger.
author: Seneca

text: It is quality rather than quantity that matters.
author: Seneca

text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
author: Seneca

text: A gem cannot be polished without friction, nor a man perfected without trials.
author: Seneca

text: There is no genius without a touch of madness.
author: Seneca

text: To wish to be well is a part of becoming well.
author: Seneca

text: You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.
author: Seneca

text: The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today.
author: Seneca

text: It is not that we have so little time but that we lose so much.
author: Seneca

text: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
author: Seneca

text: As long as you live, keep learning how to live.
author: Seneca

text: Anger, if not restrained, is frequently more hurtful to us than the injury that provokes it.
author: Seneca

text: We should every night call ourselves to account: What infirmity have I mastered today? What passion opposed?
author: Seneca

text: The bravest sight in the world is to see a great man struggling against adversity.
author: Seneca

text: Religion is regarded by the common people as true, by the wise as false, and by rulers as useful.
author: Seneca

text: Enjoy present pleasures in such a way as not to injure future ones.
author: Seneca

text: You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Very little is needed to make a happy life; it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The best revenge is not to be like your enemy.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it, if you have to, with the same weapons of reason.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The soul becomes dyed with the color of its thoughts.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: If it is not right, do not do it; if it is not true, do not say it.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Look back over the past, with its changing empires that rose and fell, and you can foresee the future too.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Death smiles at us all; all we can do is smile back.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: It is not death that a man should fear, but he should fear never beginning to live.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: When you arise in the morning, think of what a privilege it is to be alive, to think, to enjoy, to love.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Reject your sense of injury and the injury itself disappears.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Loss is nothing else but change, and change is nature's delight.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Do not act as if you had ten thousand years to throw away. Death stands at your elbow. Be good for something while you live.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The art of living is more like wrestling than dancing.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Begin each day by telling yourself: Today I shall be meeting with interference, ingratitude, insolence, disloyalty, ill-will, and selfishness.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Think of yourself as dead. You have lived your life. Now take what's left and live it properly.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: A man's worth is no greater than the worth of his ambitions.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Nowhere can man find a quieter or more untroubled retreat than in his own soul.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything which happens in life.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: If someone is able to show me that what I think or do is not right, I will happily change.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: What we do now echoes in eternity.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Remember that very little is needed to make a happy life.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Our life is what our thoughts make it.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Do every act of your life as though it were the very last act of your life.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: No man can escape his destiny, the next inquiry being how he may best live the time that he has to live.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
author: Epictetus

text: First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
author: Epictetus

text: No man is free who is not master of himself.
author: Epictetus

text: Make the best use of what is in your power, and take the rest as it happens.
author: Epictetus

text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
author: Epictetus

text: Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it.
author: Epictetus

text: He who laughs at himself never runs out of things to laugh at.
author: Epictetus

text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
author: Epictetus

text: Circumstances don't make the man, they only reveal him to himself.
author: Epictetus

text: You are not your body and hair-style, but your capacity for choosing well.
author: Epictetus

text: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master; he can anger you only when you permit yourself to be disturbed by him.
author: Epictetus

text: It is impossible for a man to learn what he thinks he already knows.
author: Epictetus

text: We have two ears and one mouth so that we can listen twice as much as we speak.
author: Epictetus

text: Seek not the good in external things; seek it in yourselves.
author: Epictetus

text: Only the educated are free.
author: Epictetus

text: Men are disturbed not by things, but by the views which they take of them.
author: Epictetus

text: If you would be a reader, read; if a writer, write.
author: Epictetus

text: Know, first, who you are, and then adorn yourself accordingly.
author: Epictetus

text: We cannot choose our external circumstances, but we can always choose how we respond to them.
author: Epictetus

text: Caretake this moment. Immerse yourself in its particulars. Respond to this person, this challenge, this deed.
author: Epictetus

text: Freedom is the only worthy goal in life. It is won by disregarding things that lie beyond our control.
author: Epictetus

text: He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.
author: Epictetus

text: The key is to keep company only with people who uplift you, whose presence calls forth your best.
author: Epictetus

text: Practice yourself, for heaven's sake, in little things; and thence proceed to greater.
author: Epictetus

text: Remember that you are an actor in a drama, of such a kind as the author pleases to make it.
author: Epictetus

text: When someone is properly grounded in life, they shouldn't have to look outside themselves for approval.
author: Epictetus

text: Suffering arises from trying to control what is uncontrollable, or from neglecting what is within our power.
author: Epictetus

text: Other people's views and troubles can be contagious. Don't sabotage yourself by unwittingly adopting negative attitudes.
author: Epictetus

text: Be not swept off your feet by the vividness of the impression, but say, 'Wait for me a little; let me see what you are.'
author: Epictetus

text: What would have become of Hercules do you think if there had been no lion, hydra, stag or boar? What would he have done in the absence of such challenges?
author: Epictetus

text: The three big ones in life are wealth, health, and happiness. We pursue them in that order, but their importance is reverse.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: A calm mind, a fit body, and a house full of love. These things cannot be bought — they must be earned.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Learn to sell. Learn to build. If you can do both, you will be unstoppable.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Desire is a contract you make with yourself to be unhappy until you get what you want.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: All the real benefits in life come from compound interest.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The most important skill for getting rich is becoming a perpetual learner.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: If you can't see yourself working with someone for life, don't work with them for a day.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Reading is the ultimate meta-skill and can be traded for anything else.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Happiness is the absence of striving for happiness.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Specific knowledge is found by pursuing your genuine curiosity and passion rather than whatever is hot right now.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Play long-term games with long-term people. All returns in life come from compound interest over many turns of the game.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Free education is abundant, all over the internet. It's the desire to learn that's scarce.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The hardest thing is not doing what you want — it's knowing what you want.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: You're not going to get rich renting out your time. You must own equity to gain your financial freedom.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Escape competition through authenticity. When you're competing with others, it's because you're copying them.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: If you're not willing to be misunderstood, you will never do anything new.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Retirement is when you stop sacrificing today for an imaginary tomorrow. You've reached retirement when you're doing what you would do even if you weren't getting paid.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The modern struggle: Lone individuals summoning inhuman willpower, fasting, meditating, and exercising, up against armies of scientists and statisticians weaponizing abundant food, screens, and medicine.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Peace is happiness at rest. Happiness is peace in motion.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: If you have everything you want, are you happy right this second? If not, why not?
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Seek wealth, not money or status. Wealth is having assets that earn while you sleep.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The best founders I've found are the ones who are very long-term thinkers. They have a strong vision for the world.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Judgment — especially demonstrated judgment, with high accountability and a clear track record — is critical.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: You should be too busy to have dinner parties with your friends every week, but not so busy that you never have dinner with your friends.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: We spend our whole life trying to be great at something. The great are just ones who work endlessly at getting great at one thing.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The reality is life is a single-player game. You're born alone. You die alone. All of your interpretations are alone.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: Cynicism is easy. Mimicry is easy. Optimistic contrarians are the rarest breed.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: No one can compete with you on being you. Most of life is a search for who and what needs you the most.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: A happy person isn't someone who's happy all the time. It's someone who effortlessly interprets events in such a way that they don't lose their innate peace.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: If you want to be successful, surround yourself with people who are more successful than you. If you want to be happy, surround yourself with people who are less successful than you.
author: Naval Ravikant

text: The only way to make sense out of change is to plunge into it, move with it, and join the dance.
author: Alan Watts

text: Muddy water is best cleared by leaving it alone.
author: Alan Watts

text: This is the real secret of life — to be completely engaged with what you are doing in the here and now.
author: Alan Watts

text: You are an aperture through which the universe is looking at and exploring itself.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: The meaning of life is just to be alive. It is so plain and so obvious and so simple.
author: Alan Watts

text: Problems that remain persistently insoluble should always be suspected as questions asked in the wrong way.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: Trying to define yourself is like trying to bite your own teeth.
author: Alan Watts

text: No one is more dangerously insane than one who is sane all the time.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: Every intelligent individual wants to know what makes him tick, and yet is at once fascinated and frustrated by the fact that oneself is the most difficult of all things to know.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: We seldom realize that our most private thoughts and emotions are not actually our own.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: We do not come into this world; we come out of it, as leaves from a tree.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: Man suffers only because he takes seriously what the gods made for fun.
author: Alan Watts

text: To have faith is to trust yourself to the water. When you swim you don't grab hold of the water, because if you do you will sink and drown.
author: Alan Watts

text: The art of living is neither careless drifting on the one hand nor fearful clinging to the past on the other.
author: Alan Watts

text: Running away from fear is fear; fighting pain is pain; trying to be brave is being scared.
author: Alan Watts

text: We are living in a culture entirely hypnotized by the illusion of time.
author: Alan Watts

text: Things are as they are. Looking out into the universe at night, we make no comparisons between right and wrong stars, nor between well and badly arranged constellations.
author: Alan Watts

text: You and I are all as much continuous with the physical universe as a wave is continuous with the ocean.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: Zen does not confuse spirituality with thinking about God while one is peeling potatoes. Zen spirituality is just to peel the potatoes.
author: Alan Watts

text: Tomorrow and plans for tomorrow can have no significance at all unless you are in full contact with the reality of the present.
author: Alan Watts

text: No work is stressful. It is your inability to manage your body, mind, and emotions that makes it stressful.
author: Alan Watts

text: The past and future are real illusions, that they exist in the present, which is what there is and all there is.
author: Alan Watts

text: What I am really saying is that you don't need to do anything, because if you see yourself in the correct way, you are all as much extraordinary phenomenon of nature as trees, clouds, the patterns in running water.
author: Alan Watts

text: The menu is not the meal.
author: Alan Watts
source: The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are

text: The more a thing tends to be permanent, the more it tends to be lifeless.
author: Alan Watts

text: Waking up to who you are requires letting go of who you imagine yourself to be.
author: Alan Watts

text: A scholar tries to learn something everyday; a student of Buddhism tries to unlearn something daily.
author: Alan Watts

text: Advice? I don't have advice. Stop aspiring and start writing. If you're writing, you're a writer. Write like you're a goddamn death row inmate and the governor is out of the country.
author: Alan Watts

text: But I'll tell you what hermits realize. If you go off into a far, far forest and get very quiet, you'll come to understand that you're connected with everything.
author: Alan Watts

text: Life is like music for its own sake. We are living in an eternal now, and when we listen to music we are not listening to the past, we are not listening to the future, we are listening to an expanded present.
author: Alan Watts

text: You must never confuse faith that you will prevail in the end with the discipline to confront the most brutal facts of your current reality.
author: James Stockdale
source: Stockdale Paradox, via Good to Great
context: From his experience as a POW in Vietnam

text: I never lost faith in the end of the story. I never doubted that I would get out, and that I would turn the experience into the defining event of my life.
author: James Stockdale

text: The optimists were the ones who didn't make it. They said we'd be out by Christmas, and then by Easter, and then by Thanksgiving. They died of a broken heart.
author: James Stockdale

text: Life is not fair. The hero is often penalized, while the coward is rewarded. But the hero doesn't care.
author: James Stockdale
source: Courage Under Fire: Testing Epictetus's Doctrines

text: The world can take anything from you — everything — except your freedom to choose how you respond.
author: James Stockdale
source: Thoughts of a Philosophical Fighter Pilot
